item.title: Eyes Potential Threat From China's Digital Yuan Plans...
item.description:
finance.yahoo.com
(Bloomberg) -- The Biden administration is stepping up scrutiny of China‚Äôs plans for a digital yuan, with some officials concerned the move could kick off a long-term bid to topple the dollar as the world‚Äôs dominant reserve currency, according to people familiar with the matter.Now that China‚Äôs digital-currency efforts are gathering momentum, officials at the Treasury, State Department, Pentagon and National Security Council are bolstering their efforts to understand the potential implications, the people said.American officials are less worried about an immediate challenge to the current structure of the global financial system, but are eager to understand how the digital yuan will be distributed, and whether it could also be used to work around U.S. sanctions, the people said on the condition of anonymity.A Treasury spokeswoman declined to comment. A National Security Council spokeswoman did not reply to a request for comment.The People‚Äôs Bank of China has rolled out trial issuance of a digital yuan in cities across the country, putting it on track to be the first major central bank to issue a virtual currency. A broader roll-out is expected for the Winter Olympics in Beijing next February, giving the effort international exposure.Many key details of the digital yuan are still in flux, including specifics on how it would be distributed. China‚Äôs recent establishment of a joint venture with SWIFT, the messaging nexus through which most cross-border settlements pass through today, suggests it is possible a digital yuan could work within the current financial architecture rather than outside of it.U.S. officials are reassured that China‚Äôs intentions aren‚Äôt to use the digital yuan to evade American sanctions, according to people familiar with the matter. The dollar‚Äôs current dominance in cross-border transactions gives the U.S. Treasury the power to cut off much of a business or even a country‚Äôs access to the global financial system.China‚Äôs officials have said the main intentions of the digital yuan are to replace banknotes and coins, to reduce the incentive to use cryptocurrencies and to complement the current private-sector run electronic payments system -- dominated by Ant Group Co.‚Äôs Alipay and Tencent Holdings Ltd.‚Äôs WeChat Pay. The PBOC has been working for years on the digital yuan, also called the e-CNY, having set up a specialist research team in 2014.Here‚Äôs How a Central Bank Digital Currency Could Work: Chart‚Äã‚Äã‚ÄúTo provide a backup or redundancy for the retail payment system, the central bank has to step up‚Äù and provide digital-currency services, Mu Changchun, the director of the PBOC‚Äôs digital-currency research institute, said at an event last month.Beyond seeking a backup to privately run e-payments, Chinese regulators have more broadly been expanding their oversight of the country‚Äôs digital champions. Ant Group was told by Beijing to become a financial holding company, which will be regulated more like a bank. China also imposed a $2.8 billion antitrust fine on Ant‚Äôs affiliate Alibaba Group Holding Ltd.Read More: Ant to Be Financial Holding Firm in Overhaul Forced by ChinaThe PBOC is also examining the potential for using the digital yuan in cross-border payments, launching a project studying the issue with a unit of the Bank for International Settlements along with the United Arab Emirates, Thailand and Hong Kong‚Äôs monetary authority.The Biden administration isn‚Äôt currently planning to take any action to counter longer-term threats from China‚Äôs digital currency, the people familiar with the discussions said. However, China‚Äôs plans have given renewed impetus to efforts to consider the creation of a digital dollar, they said.Members of Congress have also been increasingly interested in a digital dollar, aware of China‚Äôs moves, and asked Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell and Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen about the issue in hearings earlier this year.Powell: Need for Digital Dollar Is an Issue for Congress, PublicPowell said in February the Fed was looking ‚Äúvery carefully‚Äù at a digital dollar. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt need to be the first. We need to get it right.‚ÄùYellen has signaled interest in research into the viability of a digital dollar, a shift from a lack of enthusiasm under her predecessor, Steven Mnuchin.‚ÄúIt makes sense for central banks to be looking at‚Äù issuing sovereign digital currencies, she said at a virtual conference in February. Yellen said a digital version of the dollar could help address hurdles to financial inclusion in the U.S. among low-income households.A recent report from the U.S. Director of National Intelligence said the extent of the threat of any foreign digital currency to the dollar‚Äôs centrality in the global financial system ‚Äúwill depend on the regulatory rules that are established.‚ÄùChina‚Äôs currency makes up little more than 2% of global foreign exchange reserves compared with nearly 60% for the U.S. dollar. Policy decisions, rather than technical developments, will also be necessary to push forward yuan internationalization, as China maintains a strict regime of capital controls.China‚Äôs financial system is too ‚Äúfragile and weak‚Äù to pose a real threat to the dollar‚Äôs status as the world‚Äôs reserve currency, according to Mark Sobel, U.S. chairman for the Official Monetary and Financial Institutions Forum.‚ÄúAt the end of the the day the markets have more confidence in the Fed‚Äù than China‚Äôs central bank, said Sobel, a former senior U.S. Treasury official for international matters.(Adds reference to China‚Äôs regulatory measures in 10th paragraph.)For more articles like this, please visit us at bloomberg.comSubscribe now to stay ahead with the most trusted business news source.¬©2021 Bloomberg L.P.

item.title: Brits Get Morning Drunk in the Snow to Celebrate Grand Reopening...
item.description:
news.yahoo.com
ITV NewsIt‚Äôs been a long, cold, lonely winter in England.So, as four months of a nationwide lockdown finally came to an end, nothing was going to stop people from enjoying a refreshing pint of beer at the crack of dawn on a Monday morning‚Äînot even driving rain, freezing temperatures, and some pretty unseasonal snowfall.Pubs started serving outdoors again as part of a reopening plan that also covers indoor gym sessions, swimming pools, non-essential shops, beauty salons, and, for those who have been gagging to see some sad animals, zoos. Prime Minister Boris Johnson had urged people to ‚Äúbehave responsibly‚Äù with their new freedoms, but didn‚Äôt explicitly say they shouldn‚Äôt get drunk in the snow before having breakfast.One pub in the town of Huddersfield was swamped when it opened at the stroke of midnight. ‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt even know if anyone was going to come,‚Äù said the pub landlord fittingly named Ian Snowball. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs in Huddersfield, it‚Äôs midnight, it‚Äôs freezing cold‚Äîbut look, everyone has come.‚ÄùIf you thought you were starting early today‚Ä¶ üçªThese drinkers in Huddersfield braved the snow to enjoy a beer garden pint at midnight ‚ùÑÔ∏èhttps://t.co/UASiR7bXEv pic.twitter.com/i2O79eocSR‚Äî BBC Breakfast (@BBCBreakfast) April 12, 2021 One drinker commented matter-of-factly: ‚ÄúIt was snowing earlier but I was still going to come out, I just put my coat on.‚Äù Another, sitting in a thick jacket next to an icy-looking gin and tonic, made the fair point: ‚ÄúAfter 14 months of not going anywhere, except funerals, it‚Äôs a great place.‚ÄùSky News reported that 50 pub-goers headed to the Fox On The Hill pub in south London this morning. The most emotional was perhaps Tony Blake, 59, who gushed to the news network: ‚ÄúI am so happy that it‚Äôs open again, it‚Äôs unbelievable, I‚Äôm so happy.‚Äù Student Sasha Carrington, 19, said she planned to stay there for the entire freezing cold day, explaining: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got our layers on, thermals, we‚Äôre going to stay outside.‚ÄùPippa Ingram, 51, and Sue Bell, 55, celebrated a chilly seaside pint in Kent, with Ingram describing her first sip in detail. ‚ÄúAbsolutely delicious,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not gonna last long at all! That is banging.‚Äù Back in Huddersfield, in footage timestamped at 8.17 a.m., a woman identified only as Sandy was seen having pints with her friends, and she told Good Morning Britain: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that cold after a while when you‚Äôre sat in the sun.‚ÄùAs pub gardens reopen from today, @NickDixonITV talks to some people who have enjoyed a pint since 8am this morning.They discuss how happy they are to be back in pub gardens following the lockdown.Watch GMB üëâ https://t.co/6iQ6ebeOEQ pic.twitter.com/W0yAai1tGD‚Äî Good Morning Britain (@GMB) April 12, 2021 One pub in Coventry appears to have taken things slightly too far. Videos posted online showed more than 100 people lining the street outside the Oak Inn after it had publized its grand plans to open a massive outdoor space with heaters, marquees and blankets. The pub is now under investigation for its ‚Äúunmanageable amounts of visitors.‚ÄùBut, largely, the grand reopening has been welcomed as a major landmark‚Äîparticularly following the success of the Britain‚Äôs vaccine rollout, which has many hoping that there won‚Äôt be another lockdown. Nicholas Hair, landlord of the Kentish Belle in south-east London, told BBC News that there was a ‚Äúsense of celebration‚Äù in the country, adding: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm hoping this is a sort of rebirth, and that we‚Äôre reopen for the foreseeable.‚ÄùAs for Boris himself, government sources confirmed that the prime minister received a long-awaited haircut on Monday‚Äîbut his planned trip to the pub has been cancelled out of respect for the late Prince Philip.Read more at The Daily Beast.Get our top stories in your inbox every day. Sign up now!Daily Beast Membership: Beast Inside goes deeper on the stories that matter to you. Learn more.

item.title: The Shady Crypto Start-Up Selling 'Shares' in Celebs...
item.description:
news.yahoo.com
Photo Illustration by The Daily Beast / Photos via Getty/ReutersIn late March, a 23-year-old named Alex Masmej logged on to Twitter to learn he had been turned into a currency. On a new social networking platform called BitClout, anyone with access to Bitcoin could, in just a few steps, buy something called the ‚Äúalexmasmej‚Äù coin. A handful of people already had‚Äîthere were about 24 coins in circulation. By BitClout‚Äôs metric, a piece of Alex cost about $250.This was not an entirely new experience for Masmej. Last year, after losing his job in the pandemic, he‚Äôd minted his own coin called the $ALEX token, selling what amounted to shares in his life. The first $ALEX investors to help Masmej raise $20,000 would get 15 percent of his income for the next three years; at times, they could vote on his everyday decisions. In concept, the BitClout coin was similar, but with a key difference: He‚Äôd had nothing to do with it.‚ÄúBitClout does not ask for consent,‚Äù Masmej told the Daily Beast. ‚Äú[It] is trading on your name without you knowing‚Ä¶ People really don‚Äôt like this, and that makes sense because it seems almost illegal.‚ÄùThe platform, which has become a source of anger and bemusement in the pockets of the internet that pay attention to new crypto projects, operates sort of like a monetized Twitter. BitClout lets people speculate on prominent social media figures, buying personalized tokens that theoretically rise and fall in value with the person‚Äôs popularity. The combination of hype technology and celebrity proved attractive to investors, raising over $165 million from Andreessen Horowitz, the Winklevoss twins, and Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian. But the project‚Äôs critics, of which there are many, see it as a dystopian ploy to commodify human interaction, in the mode of a ‚ÄúYelp for people.‚ÄùMasmej wasn‚Äôt the only one to find himself minted into money. When BitClout launched out of private beta on March 24, some 14,000 users had pre-made profiles on the platform, copied from their Twitter accounts and converted into markets for individualized coins, nearly all without approval. Elon Musk, the top-ranked token on the website, runs for about $77,000; Ariana Grande goes for just under $25,000. Donald Trump, who places slightly below Barstool Sports‚Äô Dave Portnoy (about $17,000), trades for nearly $15,700.Masmej found the platform funny, but others were not as entertained. The crypto-focused law firm Anderson Kill sent BitClout a cease-and-desist on behalf of a product manager at the token exchange Radar Relay, calling for his likeness to be removed from the site. ‚ÄúIt is well established that a person or company cannot knowingly use ‚Äòanother‚Äôs name, voice, signature, photograph or likeness‚Ä¶for purposes of advertising or selling...without such person‚Äôs prior consent,‚Äù the letter reads, citing the right of publicity under California Civil Code 3344. The account was removed, but users can still technically buy its coin by searching for the original username.The premise of BitClout is fairly straightforward. Traders exchange Bitcoin for the site‚Äôs native currency, BitClout, which they must spend to register an account, send messages, or post. They can also use the currency to buy ‚ÄúCreator Coins,‚Äù individualized tokens issued for prominent personalities. The more people buy a given Creator Coin, the more its value rises, and vice-versa. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs literally tokenized clout,‚Äù said Brian Fakhoury, a crypto investor who has written about the platform. ‚ÄúThe more clout you have, the more your thing is worth.‚ÄùThe site is set up to capitalize on the clout of its users, requiring the most well-known accounts to engage in a bit of unpaid advertising. Figures like Masmej, whose profiles were pre-made on the site, can claim their accounts and issue tokens on their own behalf‚Äîbut only if they buy BitClout and tweet about the platform. Very few people have done this. One source who reviewed the website‚Äôs backend said about 80 profiles on the platform had been claimed.Should I claim my Bitclout?‚Äî Snoop Dogg (@SnoopDogg) April 7, 2021 Just joined #BitClout! Excited to be a part of a new platform in the crypto space. Follow me at: https://t.co/XMkeLVV5oC BC1YLiySbpLp3y6q279SQXPgLZPqQoMxKHE9ToqDFk56jE9kwbF4gXE‚Äî Tiffany Ariana Trump (@TiffanyATrump) April 7, 2021 BitClout‚Äôs launch arrived on the heels of the craze over NFTs, or ‚Äúnon-fungible tokens,‚Äù cryptographic units of data stored on a blockchain that can be minted in a range of formats‚ÄîJack Dorsey turned his first tweet into an NFT; Kings of Leon released an album as one‚Äîand sold off for increasingly outrageous prices. BitClout operates on a similar premise: minting tokens that market hype as a way to directly pay creators. But while NFTs are not mutually interchangeable‚Äîthe owner of Dorsey‚Äôs tweet NFT cannot trade it for another version‚ÄîBitClout is. Like a dollar, the token can be exchanged for other BitClout. It‚Äôs a fungible token.‚ÄúThe underlying force of NFTs is the exact same thing that drives BitClout,‚Äù Fakhoury said. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs the same thing at the end of the day. They're kind of worthless assets that people give value to for no underlying reason.‚ÄùBetween NFTs, now BitClout, sometimes I wonder if we‚Äôre living in a simulation ü§ñ Things will only get weirder from here .. üëΩ‚Äî Abigail Ratchford (@AbiRatchford) April 3, 2021 When it launched, BitClout‚Äôs creator tried to remain anonymous, identifying himself only as ‚ÄúDiamondhands‚Äù‚Äîa slang term for someone who holds onto their financial position fiercely‚Äîin the mold of Bitcoin‚Äôs pseudonymous inventor, Satoshi Nakamoto. But the attempt at secrecy crumbled quickly, when industry insiders pointed to a man named Nader Al-Naji, who later confirmed his identity to the trade publication, Decrypt. (Al-Naji did not respond to the Daily Beast‚Äôs request for comment).A former Google engineer from Alexandria, Virginia, Al-Naji made a splash in the crypto-world back in 2018 with a project called Basis. The idea was to create what‚Äôs called a ‚Äústable coin‚Äù‚Äîa token whose value is pegged to a more reliable currency, like the U.S. dollar‚Äîbut to establish that stability with an algorithm, rather than backing it with actual money. Al-Naji raised a record-breaking $133 million in seed funding, but the concept proved unsustainable. After the Securities and Exchange Commission got involved, Basis shut down and returned its remaining money to investors.The failure left Al-Naji with a mixed reputation: a founder who stumbled, but didn‚Äôt steal. And yet the launch of BitClout, which one investor described to Decrypt as ‚Äúfucked up,‚Äù has struck many as a scam. The biggest red flag, beyond the glaring consent issue, is that while users can put money into BitClout, they cannot get it out. Traders send Bitcoin to a single account run by the BitClout team‚Äîthe exact ownership of which remains unknown‚Äîbut it‚Äôs a one-way transaction. The currency does not trade on any exchanges and there‚Äôs no way to cash out on the website.Anyone looking to actually profit from their trades on BitClout has to take more surreptitious measures. Aravind Karthigeyan, a high school student and moderator of a BitClout subreddit, told The Daily Beast he‚Äôs gotten around this by reselling his tokens at a discount to individual buyers on the messaging app, Telegram.For James Prestwich, a crypto engineer and founder who has been publicly critical of BitClout, this represents a clear indication that the currency is a shitcoin‚Äîcrypto jargon for a scam. ‚ÄúThe only way to get Bitcoin or dollars out is to find another person and to negotiate a bespoke deal with them,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSo BitClout users, once they get in, they're trapped. There's no way out.‚Äù‚ÄúThere is a secondary market that‚Äôs developed on Telegram. On Telegram, OTC (over-the-counter) BitClout is usually a 40 to 50 percent discount,‚Äù Prestwich said. ‚ÄúSo if you want to get out, you‚Äôre taking a 40 percent haircut, and the only way to do it is to manually send the BitClout to someone and hope they pay you.‚ÄùCritics have also cast doubt on the platform‚Äôs security. ‚ÄúThey are very opaque,‚Äù Masmej said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very hard to get to the BitClout website‚Ä¶ and even then, it‚Äôs really hard on the platform to know how much they‚Äôre getting in fees or what exactly to do to sign up. We have to pay Bitcoin, but we don‚Äôt really know what it‚Äôs for. I think a lot of communities in crypto are really pissed off.‚ÄùMost crypto projects issue users a ‚Äúprivate key‚Äù‚Äîoften a long phrase or string of random characters‚Äîto access their accounts. Unlike a password, private keys can‚Äôt be changed. The risk is that if someone else figures out a private key, the user can‚Äôt make a new one to keep them out of the account. ‚ÄúIf somebody gets your private key, you literally can't do anything with your account,‚Äù Fakhoury said. ‚ÄúIt is just forever compromised.‚ÄùBitClout also issues private keys, but when users log in, it caches the keys in whatever browser they‚Äôre using. As a result, the keys are more vulnerable to theft‚Äîif the user clicks on a scammy pfishing link and signs in, their key could be stolen. ‚ÄúThere's a big security risk in the private keys just sitting directly in your browser,‚Äù Fakhoury said.For Prestwich, the more jarring revelation was that BitClout also stores the keys on its own server, uploading the data after every transaction. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not just that they‚Äôre insecurely storing keys, but they‚Äôre sending them to themselves,‚Äù Prestwich said. ‚ÄúThey could take all of the BitClout at any time or make arbitrary purchases on your behalf. Any BitClout you have, any employee that has access to that server can take it at any time.‚ÄùRather than launching the platform on a ready-made blockchain like the Bitcoin-rival Ethereum, which has templates for minting new tokens using its own infrastructure, BitClout chose to develop their protocol from scratch. As a result, it was not initially a blockchain‚Äîwhere multiple servers run the same algorithm and register transactions simultaneously‚Äîbut a single block or ‚Äúnode‚Äù operated off one server.In its white paper, BitClout claims that other users are running nodes. And the project maintains that it is open-source, meaning anyone interested could theoretically download the source code, create a node of their own, and extend the chain. But BitClout‚Äôs creator has not released the source code. ‚ÄúThere does seem to be a blockchain there,‚Äù Prestwich said, ‚Äúa poorly constructed, poorly thought out blockchain. I would suspect that there are other people who have a close relationship with BitClout who are running other nodes.‚ÄùAs an investor, Fakhoury was skeptical of the project‚Äôs execution, but found the concept exciting.‚ÄúI think it's a genius idea,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBitClout just opened Pandora's box. It opens the door to now ‚ÄòOh, I see this YouTuber is getting popular. I know they're gonna get more popular now and I have a way to financially benefit from that.‚Äô‚ÄùMasmej, who has not claimed his profile because he only uses Ethereum, said his peers were less impressed. ‚ÄúI asked my friends in crypto and they were like ‚ÄòDude, this is a chain for boomers,‚Äô‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey are only on Bitcoin, this is not going to work, and they are impersonating people‚Äôs Twitter accounts.‚Äô‚ÄùPrestwich agreed: ‚ÄúThis is not the cool, hot crypto-startup. This is people who are part of the establishment trying to imitate some of the hot crypto-startups in order to make money.‚ÄùRead more at The Daily Beast.Got a tip? Send it to The Daily Beast hereGet our top stories in your inbox every day. Sign up now!Daily Beast Membership: Beast Inside goes deeper on the stories that matter to you. Learn more.
